description._content: Ten a.m.  This bear apparently did not get the memo that they only visit feeders at night. Notice that the feeder is GONE. It knocked it down yesterday afternoon, so no more bird feeding for a while.
Near Floating Island Lake

After several years finally was able to get one on camera
This Mexican black bear was seen twice during our stay in the Chisos Basin. It was an emaciated adult male that apparently got his growth stunted by the historic 2011 drought. Brewster Co, TX.

Black Himalayan Bear
The patch on his chest gave the impression of a necklace the bear was wear

Mother black bear growling at her cubs to climb higher because human (me) was getting closer.  I took this pic and slowly walked backwards to my bike on BB and pedaled fast before she could attack me. lol     This is on Susan Rd. off of BB near Pattison State Park near Superior, WI

Black.title: American Black Bear, Cinnamon subspecies (Ursus americanus cinnamomum) D7K_7871

description._content: Cinnamon Bear, a subspecies of American Black Bear, feeding on an elk carcass along Antelope Creek, Yellowstone National Park. The kill was made by wolves, but most of the carcass was devoured by two Cinnamon Bears who competed for the feast while at least one wolf kept watch.

Black.title: Why'd The Bear Cross The Road?

description._content: FOR THE EXACT SAME REASON THE CHICKEN DID, OF COURSE :-) A young Black Bear crossing the Skyline Drive at Shenandoah National Park in Virginia. View the 1000px version in the lightbox HDR -- 3 brackets from a single RAW (-2 | 0 | +2) merged and lightly tone mapped, slight crop. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ For more Black Bear photos, information and video clips, please visit the Black Bears section of my Web site or visit my Black Bear Blogs. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- THANKS FOR VIEWING!

Grizzly bear resting on a hillside above the Lower Waterfowl Lake. Banff National Park, Alberta, Canada.

A little blond Grizzly on the shore of Kluane Lake, Yukon Territory, Canada.
This guy has been hanging around for a while digging roots
 and looks pretty scruffy and kinda sad.  We think it must have just gotten kicked out by momma this spring.
I call him the Forever Alone Grizzly.
We saw this Grizzly Bear mark on the trail at Redrock Lake, Glacier National Park. Quite impressive!!
A Grizzly Bear Cub at our Montana Wildlife Workshop
Nikon D3s and 400mm f/2.8

Sibbling grizzly cubs play fighting.  It looks serious but they are just wrestling and trying to exert some dominance over the other.  From the two times I've seen these matches go on, they seem to go about 5 or 10 minutes and then they are tired out and go back to eating.  These are two of the triplets who were recently kicked out by their mother.  The other third has gone his own way while these two have been inseperable.

Taken from the car and cropped...  Didn't seem the have the hump or the long legs of Grizzlies I have seen up north so decided just young, or the biggest brown morph of  a black bear I have every seen.  Nice reminder that we live in an incredible province were to a certain extent we can coexist.  Although the guy on the bicycle going by uphill found a new reserve of energy :)

Mary Bay yearling Grizzly cub hurries to catchup with mom in a snow flurry.
Best viewed 'L'arge.

We saw this grizzly bear cub when we were driving through the Banff National Park. It had come down to the fenceline at the side of the road. Although from these photos it looks like we were at Calgary Zoo.

We saw this grizzly bear cub when we were driving through the Banff National Park. It had come down to the fenceline at the side of the road. Although from these photos it looks like we were at Calgary Zoo.

We saw this grizzly bear cub when we were driving through the Banff National Park. It had come down to the fenceline at the side of the road. Although from these photos it looks like we were at Calgary Zoo.

We saw this grizzly bear cub when we were driving through the Banff National Park. It had come down to the fenceline at the side of the road. Although from these photos it looks like we were at Calgary Zoo.

We saw this Grizzly family at Mammoth Hot Srings in the upper terraces area. They were out for a morning stroll looking for food. This family was fun to watch as one cub would stay with mom and the other liked to venture off and explore.  Notice the third shot as one cub is trying to climb onto the boardwalk.  We are sure we viewed this family last year when the cubs were very young, as the cubs displayed these same traits.  I refer to these as "Good Cub - bad Cub."
The happy family!
Bad cub trying to climb onto the boardwalk.
Mom and good cub.

It was a warm day in Denali Thursday......
This is the grizzly's version of air conditioning :)

You can't use or post these images in other places outside my flickr account without a license or my permission.
A stare down with a Coastal British Columbia Grizzly Bear. www.brandonbroderick.com

USA, Alaska, Katmai National Park, Brown bear (Ursus arctos) at Kuliak Bay I'm not sure that I like this image as much as the other wide-angle brown bear image that I shared the other day, but what I do like is that this was created on a rare sunny day on the Katmai Coast. I've got a lot of images of bears in the rain with a telephoto lens. Yawn. I think that wide-angle images showing bears in their environment are much more interesting. Obviously, photographing bears like this requires a lot of effort in the field and being very close to bears. I do not encourage anyone without experience around bears to try creating images like this. However, many of the bears on the outer coast of Katmai National Park are not afraid of humans and under most conditions, do not perceive us as threats. It was a privilege to be so close to these wild animals. I created this image using my Canon 5DmkII, 17-40mm f4 lens, and Singh-Ray 2-stop Hard GND filter. I remotely triggered the camera using 2 PocketWizards, but I was sitting not too far to away. This image is a single-exposure which required minimal processing using Aperture 3 and Photoshop CS5. You can also +1 me on Google+, "Like" my Fan Page on Facebook, or follow me on Twitter.

Many of you may have heard of or seen Grizzly 399, for she is a very well known grizzly bear in Grand Teton National Park.  I very much wanted to see and photograph this "celebearty" myself, for I'd never had the pleasure before.  I did manage to photograph her two daughters from her 2006 litter, but never the matriarch herself. For those of you who are unfamiliar with her legacy, here is a brief synopsis.  In 2006 she gave birth to three cubs and raised them near the roadsides close to Oxbow Bend.  She did a fine job too as all three cubs reached independence.  Unfortunately, not all of their stories ended well.  One of her offspring (known as "Grizzly 615") was shot and killed by a hunter in an act of "self defense" (while on his way to dress a deer kill) who was approached too closely by the young female bear.  That is if 40 yards is too close and the bear, who was feeding on a moose carcass and never actually moved toward the hunter other than to raise on her hind legs for a better perspective was approaching too close.  Her one male cub was relocated to one of the surrounding national forests because he was hanging around houses that directly boarder the park off of Pacific Creek Road.  The male bear eventually was relocated back to Grand Teton after killing a cow.  I am unsure as to his whereabouts now.  The third cub from 399’s brood has been captured and tagged and she is now known as "Grizzly 610", or just "610" for those who don't like formalities.  In 2011 Grizzly 399 had three cubs while Grizzly 610 had two of her own.  As is common among bears, and many animals for that matter, 610’s home range overlapped that of her mother and occasionally they would cross paths, peacefully, which is nice.  During one of these get togethers one of 399’s cubs joined 610’s twins and off they went, Grizzly 399 left with two and 610 left with three.  Fast forward to this spring where we find Grizzly 610 delighting crowds with three second year cubs in tow, however, Grizzly 399 had been seen going solo.  She either chased off her cubs (a year too early) or they got separated.  The youngsters have been seen together quite often and seem to be doing relatively well, despite their early independence.  I am not sure of the true nature of the parting, but when I saw the grand matriarch she was sans cubs.  

A sad note, a young male grizzly was struck and killed by a car on Highway 191/26/89, which bisects Grand Teton, this morning.  Although it is unclear who the bear is, whether it is one of 399's offspring or not, it is a sad story to read and shines a bright spotlight on the difficulties of these wonderful creatures.

no HDR

GaizAtTheWorld.com

This is as close to grizzly bear comedy as I've been able to capture.  This young male grizzly was walking towards me, seemingly daring me to get off 'his' road.  I was standing beside my pickup looking through the lens and once in a while looking up and realizing how close he was getting.

Will he walk off to the side of the road?  Dare I stand my ground and get a better photo?  How much closer can I let him get?

I wonder if he's thinking similar thoughts?  How much closer do I dare get to this weird thing on wheels and man with funny looking thing in front of his face?

He looks confused.  Tilts his head and gives me a funny sideways look.  The crossover step was just too funny.  It looks like he is torn between a right turn and a left.  I was lucky to capture this moment of indecision.  I wonder what he thought when I laughed out loud and he walked off the road to my left.

USA, Alaska, Katmai National Park, Brown bear (Ursus arctos) at Kukak Bay "Who's a happy bear?" That is what I would say to a big-old male brown bear who was sitting by the river during my expedition to the Katmai Coast last August. The bears always seemed so casual as they waited for salmon to pretty much swim into their mouths. I spent a lot of time watching them sleep with one eye open, which doesn't make for a great picture. However, every once in a while one would "do something", like this bear sitting on its haunches itching a nagging scratch. I got down really low to the ground with my camera in order to render the distant trees as pleasing bokeh. I created this image with my Canon 7D and 500mm f4 IS lens. This image is a single-exposure which required minimal processing using Aperture 3 and Photoshop CS5. You can also +1 me on Google+, "Like" my Fan Page on Facebook, or follow me on Twitter.

My friends and I spent quite a bit of time phtographing this grizz from a safe distance. When she suddenly decided to cross the road, it was a quick escape into the car, leaving our tripods to be collected after she sauntered away.

no HDR

description._content:
I'd left the elephants, and was heading back to the Big Cat enclosure to see what the tiger cubs were doing.

The route takes me past Bethyl's enclosure, and i was lucky enough to see her sitting in her pool, with just her head above water. I managed to get some shots of her as she came out of the pool.

Bethyl turned 35 on 18th Jan 2012.

I'd left the elephants, and was heading back to the Big Cat enclosure to see what the tiger cubs were doing.

The route takes me past Bethyl's enclosure, and i was lucky enough to see her sitting in her pool, with just her head above water. I managed to get some shots of her as she came out of the pool.

Bethyl turned 35 on 18th Jan 2012.

Brown Bear on the tundra of Southeastern Alaska
Coastal Grizzly catching a Sockeye Salmon on Lake Kukaklek Lake
I love seeing that the bears use their hands for gripping like this
I've got a stick!
Wazzzzuuuuuuuuup???
One of the cubs looking up at me like "So could we play a game of fetch?  Just let me out there..."
So...do you bears come here often?
Evidently bears just crack themselves up

Kitty. 

Kitty is a young Kodiak brown bear. Her claws can tear you apart. If she wanted, she could stomp on you using these feet and crush your entire chest cavity.
Taken at Zoom Erlebniswelt in Gelsenkirchen, Germany.  Here Brenda tries to entice her lazy partner out of bed with some kind or treat.  It didn't work.  Buffy dozed on.
Taken at Zoom Erlebniswelt in Gelsenkirchen, Germany.  I think he's dozed off for a minute here.

Monkey Design cut out postcards are very high quality - exhibiting excellent print quality, colorful design, and good directions. The postcards are produced using heavy card stock, resulting in in 3D paper art forms that are durable and do not bend or sag in higher humidity environments.

A polar bear ambling along beneath the cliffs of Akpatok Island, Ungava Bay, Canada. Hundreds of thousands of Thick-billed Murres nest on the cliffs. Some of the young fall off, providing tasty treats for the bears. Photo #821 Explore the Canadian Arctic, Greenland and more with Adventure Canada
